title: What do truckers do to keep themselves entertained (and awake!) on the roads? - Quora

response.answer_text: Books on Tape, back 20 years ago all on cassette tape, longer books had 6–8 cassettes. I drove team with my Wife, and it is amazing how much we would get into these books, miles would fly by. When I drove solo, for me anyway it was very loud hard rock, and singing to it at the top of my lungs!! I sleep drove better than most, not to make light of it, it sucked, and was extremely deadly to myself and others. But it was a fact of driving for me driving solo. I would try loud music, windows down in below zero temps, slap the shit out of myself etc. One trip across Hwy 666 in New Mexico on a 2 lane stretch I woke up, looked around, saw a State Trooper beside me in the opposing lane? By the time it woke me fully he passed me the rest of the way. I have no clue how long he was there before I woke up, but he was there for a mile or so after I was alert, only saw him bend down to where he could see me once. It scared me awake till I parked it. Another trip hauling a milk tanker non-stop from Maryland I woke up almost to malfunction junction (I-75 and I-4) in Tampa, the first thing I saw were huge wide open eyes and mouths looking back at me from the Van I was coming up on at about 100 mph, I nailed the brakes, avoiding hitting them, I was still pretty out of it but also scared to death and full of adrenalin. Never had an at fault accident, and after my Wife hit the road with me never had the sleep issues as bad. And did not have to push the way I had driving solo, can not imagine the guilt and horror if I would have hurt or killed others. Sorry so long, memories flooded in when I started answering the original question.

You can park the truck and get out and run around it a couple of times. This will get the adrenaline going and help you wake up for awhile. This is time consuming because it requires stopping the truck and parking which is bad. If you don't have time to sleep you probably don't have I'm to stop and park just to jog around the truck. But it is very effective in waking the body up. The next staying awake hack is to slap yourself firmly across the face. You’lI have to do it several times on both sides of the face to get a good waking up effect. Don't be wimpy about this. If you want to be a truck driver you better get used to beating yourself up. Finally, I purchased a thermos bottle that plugged into the cigarette lighter. It will keep water scolding hot. For this hack I would recommend wearing shorts while driving. Simply take a couple ounces of the scolding hot water and pour it across your thigh. This will keep you awake for hours. If those don't work you better find another line of work. They are always hiring truck drivers in the septic tank service industry but you have to be able to take a lot of shit.

ok so this is gonna be a little controversial there are all kinds of methods used here in the states: EphedrineAdderal--no sure if that is correct spellingCocaine/MethCoffeeBC headache powder and mountain dew or coffeesunflower seedschocolateif you look back in some of my prior answers-- never ask a bullhauler for his toothpick…..there is a reason for that…..just not sure the name of that stuff-there are a lot of things that will or could or would keep you awake and alert. i was a coffee drinker, and still am-- none of my driving career was clouded by drugs-. i am proud of that…because very easily it could have turned. after yrs of experience, your body naturally enables itself to run without much need for assistance. especially when or if you drive long distances. the lack of and irregular hours by operating a truck starts to come more naturally when thats what you are use to….

Stay within your hours, sleep when you should be sleeping. A 20-minute nap will do you wonders, never go over 90-minutes unless you can sleep for at least 4 hours. For long nights, when it’s dark and the road is straight ahead, I used almonds. I would eat one almond at a time; hold it in your teeth and explore the texture with your tongue, then bite it in half at the long seam and feel the difference between the smooth inside and the rough outside. Really concentrate on that almond. Then using only your front teeth bite the almond into tiny pieces, see how small you can make them. Chew it up and move on to almond #2 If that’s not working, try doing the same thing while holding another almond between your molars and cheek. The idea is to keep your mind focused, radio doesn’t do it. Even talk radio, audiobooks, or podcasts let your mind wander, you need to have a single thought in your head.

The good news is operating a tractor trailer is much more interesting than operating a passenger vehicle. One must be alert and cognizant of your vehicle, grade, highway scenario, and more. At the wheel of a tractor trailer I can do 600 plus miles a day. If I had to do that in a car, kill me. I enjoyed satellite radio, audiobooks, and late night AM or FM radio on occasion. When I was on the road truck stop wi fi did not have enough capacity to go around. I listened to many great books on the road. Know that most public libraries these days offer free audiobook loans. After 2 weeks, the download will timebomb.

Sunflower seeds, or groundnut seeds. Listening some radio talk show, talking to a colleague on CB radio or phone. For half a year I was working with livestock carrier truck. We drove night and day, always two drivers, one was sleeping in the bed, the other was driving. After every 4 - 4 and half hours change. After unloading we cleaned the trailer, for two guys this is 4 - 5 hours hard work. I was always sleepy. Sometimes, during driving I took a bottle of mineral water from the cooler box and poured on my head. I was shivering and catching for breath, but I stayed awake for a while. Some colleagues were drinking Red Bull like water, 8 - 10 cans a night.

While driving? Music, podcasts, and audible. Many companies have cell phone policies in place to limit or prevent cell phone use while driving. Texting is a really big no-no While parked reading internet exercise eating resting visiting with people TV or movies video games sleeping polishing the truck. Pretty much what anyone would do away from home.

While driving I would listen to music talk to the family. I did sing a lot aswell.. When I was parked for my required times. Resets sleeper etc. Would shower, get some food, watch tv or play games, check my trip plans do my paperwork for the day expense sheets etc, some exercise, and then sleep. When I had time between loads and was near resorts, parks etc. I would spend some time at them.. Everyone has methods that works for them. Sometimes I would pull the grill out and make some steaks and potatoes.

There are times when u get tired but still have to drive, I always wanted to play the Harmonica, so I went to a music store as I was passing Santa Fe NM. I talked to the store owner, he said don't buy a cheap harmonica, they don't sound as nice, and they are harder to play, so I paid $65.00 and bought a Suzuki G Promaster, comes with a case, nice unit, about 12 years ago, I always leave it on the dash and when I feel like it or getting tired I pick it up and start playing it. Now I can play it farley well. I also have a hand squeezer I leave on the dash to help get the blood flowing, they both work very well for me.

I've been a long distance truck driver covering 2k-2.5k miles a week but now drive to and from Italy a few times a year in connection with my business, between 900 and 1400 miles one way depending on my destination. I rely mainly on audiobooks to enjoyably pass the time staring out the window as well as listening to podcasts and music on my IPod. To keep awake I drink coffee but when I'm really struggling to stay awake I find stopping for 20-30 minutes and power napping to work really well.

While I'm driving, I listen to music, either my own, satellite radio, or what's on the local stations, audiobooks, podcasts, sometimes news or talkshows. While I'm not driving, I have a TV, Laptop, and a Kindle, so I'm either watching movies, playing games, or reading. Sometimes if I'm in an area that has good transportation I'll get off the truck to go to a restaurant, movie theatre, or local attraction. Mostly stay close to the truck though, unless I'm somewhere with secure parking.

They have the radio on at all times and they speak to other truckers on their special radios. Sometimes, two truckers decide to play with you and they interlock you between the two of them and you cannot move out of the way for a long stretch. I had 4 small kids in the car with me and the experience was very traumatizing for me and my kifs. Also quite dangerous for I was forced to folliw their speed.

When I drove, I would not have anything on, except to CB to listen for problems coming up. Just listening to the hum of the engine and watching the world go by. Then in the afternoon when I would get a bit sleepy, turn on some tunes (I had 100 hours of rock and roll, and 100 hours of classical music-not one minute of country). Then if I were really tired, pulled off the road and took a 10–15 minute power nap to get me to the rest of the day. Nowadays, CB’s are not used much. XM satellite radio is good along with cell phones.

You can go to a drug store and buy a bottle of “caffeine tablets” that are about 200 mg per tablet. A bottle of 100 may cost about $27 or so. A pop has about 80 mg of caffeine in them. One tablet will “pick you up” a good amount without making you “wired” assuming you don’t take it after 4 pm. I don’t use my pills very often, but sometimes I am groggy, and will take one if I simply can’t become fully alert. Otherwise, I do not drink coffee or pop. I try to get good rest, and plan well, but sometimes I just need a little boost to stay safe. As far as entertainment goes, I keep plenty of audiobooks handy.

If I’m in the bunk I usually read or watch a movie on my kindle fire, If I’m stuck someplace and there’s still daylight I’ll take some photos, When I’m driving it’s mostly podcasts or I’m podcasting my adventures, most of my listeners are visually impaired or from outside the USA, I explain what I’m doing and where I’m at and what it’s like, the interaction with the people I’ve met from around the world make the day so interesting

It take some getting use to, The more you do it, The better you get. When you feel sleepy, Stop and take a nap. When I initially start driving, There was this truck stop, that was less than 200 miles from my home base. I had to stop and take a nap there. One morning I missed the exit. Ever since that morning, I could drive 500 miles or more. Without having a problem staying awake. A smart driver will stop and take a nap, If feeling sleepy.

I love my Sirius/XM satellite radio! I have access to literally anything I want (audio), from 40’s swing to 70’s folk and classic rock to 80's hair metal; from news & talk to golden age serials like The Shadow & Your's Truly, Johnny Dollar and Milton Berle, to Coast to Coast, with George Noory, it's all there. When I'm parked for the night or laid over I have dozens of DVDs, as well as a patch cable that allows me to cast streaming video programs from my smartphone onto my flat screen. Thanks for the A2A, gonna go catch up on some WSOP, now.

Here's a few tricks I've picked up from talking to drivers about this very problem. Tickle the roof of your mouth with your tongue. Pinch the inside of your thigh hard. Stop to chug a coffee. Take a twelve minute nap while the caffeine works through. You'll wake slightly refreshed and freshly buzzing. If you're a male of the species, pull out the old trouser trout and engage in some non-commital self pleasure. Perk you right up.

I’m not sure about other drivers but for me it’s my ps4 and drag tracks. When ever I have extra time on my hands I’ll find the nearest drag track grab an Uber and go watch. If I knew more people around the county and they were willing I’d love to do some fishing in new and interesting places. That’s one of the perks of being an otr trucker we get the whole USA as a playground.

First, I entertain my self by concentrating on my driving and the driving of those around me. Second, I look at all the people who pass me and especially the pretty ladies. Third, I listen to music. Fourth, I sing and I sing out loud. I think I have a great voice and can really sing loudly.

Of course, chatting on the phone on a Bluetooth with friends is always one way to go. Audio books are another diversion as well a Sirius XM radio. Don’t know what the real big rig drivers do because I just have a Freightliner and pull a large horse trailer. Maybe there will be some answers here and I’ll learn more ways to stay occupied on long trips. LOL

When you are busy you don't have much down time,if you are making money you pretty much drive sleep eat and drive some more. At one point in my career I hauled trade shows and some high value loads and would have a few days off in between shows. I always had a bicycle with me for excercise and before Ipads read a lot to pass the time.

I did not have much time for fun. First priority was to pick and deliver freight on time. Second priority was to maintain adequate nourishment and regular exercise. Third priority was to keep my mind stimulated with new information. Nonfiction or historical fiction in audio books and video tapes were my first choices. There was not much time left over to stop by the cinema for a couple of hours or take in a round of golf.

I can say the trick for me was to pick a fight with someone on the CB radio {Citizens Band). These days a lot of drivers don’t use CBs like they used to, but 15 years ago they were widely used. Most other drivers realized an argument at 2 AM was a driver trying to stay awake. The arguement could be over the stupidest things. The weather is nice…No it’s not it sucks, like your Mama.

Music!!! That’s my main entertainment while driving. I’ve also gotten into audiobooks from audible. Up until recently, I also talked on the phone -via Bluetooth -but even that’s becoming a no-no these days. When I’m parked, I like to watch tv, go for walks, read, play games on my phone, etc.

I listen to audio books, or news stations, or radio stations. Makes the time fly when you are driving. When im not driving, im either reading on my kindle or watching something on Netflix/Hulu. Canteven begin to estimate how much ive spent on dvds at truck stops in the past four years. A hint; i have TWO 500 count dvd folders FULL of dvds that cost 23.99 each, as well as like 4 or 5 smaller ones that only hold 150 each full of the 6.99 and 12.99 DVDs. You do the math.

I read books on my Kindle and watch television during my breaks . I listen to a lot of audio books while driving and also have a subscription to Sirius satellite radio and listen to a lot of football in the Fall.

Best is to get enough sleep. Secondly, if you are having trouble staying awake, pull over and have a nap. An old truck driver once told me that in response to the question about “Why are you late" the answer is “ There is a truck upside down 20 miles back, he's late. I'm here right on time". Caffeine in any form can help but if the underlying cause is lack of sleep it is can be a dangerous approach.

They have these devices called radios and phones. And this reminds me of my first real job in 1964 right out of college. The company gave salesmen company cars. In the beginning they added radios. When I started they started to add air conditioning. I got it. I remember driving with my boss and taking about the old days….” Sid. What was it like when you got company cars without radio or air conditioning. What did you do in the summer? “ I'd open the window,and hum!”

Why does everyone have to be continually entertained? Driving is one of the most complex tasks we undertake and so we should focus on that. That said, background music, audiobooks, or some days nothing. Just the whine of a turbo, the growl of the diesel motor and the wide open road is enough.

Get plenty of rest before you go start feeling sleepy roll the window down especially in cold climate 8f you need to pull over rest I 'd rather be alittle late than a serious traffic accident it only literally takes a second to dose off and a wreck can happen drink coffee Mt dew not only will the caffeine help you stay awake stopping to use the restroom will to get out walk around a little best thing take someone with you switch of driving keep each other awake. Good luck to you!

Obviously this differs from person to person. As for me, I have my notebook to practice a little coding in Python and Bash scripting and to sate my Quora habit. I also like to get in a workout whenever possible: this is a very sedentary job and, if you're not careful, you can pack on the extra pounds quickly. I still think I'm a little young for a heart attack but it can still happen very easily without some regular exercise.

We do what everyone else does we go to movies, catch up with friends and involve ourselves with our hobbies. But just between you and me? What we really do is make plans for our eventual overthrow of the world’s governments and how best to get fuel prices down to pre-1970 levels!!
First and foremost, make sure you get rest. Take as many breaks as you can. Coffee and energy drinks should be used moderately. You could open windows, pick hard driving music turned up.

Some of our drivers have hobbies and pet projects. Reading books, working out, writing and drawing, playing music, etc. Anything that requires little space in the cab, and can get your brain active away from the wheel!

It may take some time for you to get used to driving longer periods of time. Do not rush this adaptation. Get good rest and good sleep. do not short yourself on these two things. On your 10 hour Off Duty rest period, get good sleep. During your work day, of driving, when you feel sleepy, pull over to a safe haven area and take a 20 or 30 minute nap. Do not put yourself or others in danger by driving while tired and sleepy. Give your body time to adjust to these new expectations.

Get plenty of rest beforehand and if you get drowsy, stop and take a nap. Better to get there late than not at all, or hurt or kill yourself falling asleep at the wheel or, worse, injure or kill someone else.
In addition to the previous answer, some truckers carry a bicycle. The most important thing to do is get as much rest as possible to make sure you’re alert for driving
Get 8 hours of sleep the night before should do it. Also don’t drive over 11 hours. Know your limitations. If you only get a few hours of sleep the night before then your looking for a disaster.
They drive 10 hours, sleep and then drive again.
I talk on the CB and listen to the radio.
How do I stay awake while driving a truck? The same way you stay awake driving a car.

I've got an FAA approved flight simulator on my computer, V.R. headset. and flight controls. Along with a “part 61” ground school program, I study and practice for my pilots license.. when ti.e permits.
